title: Why do my parents think I'm not trying to get good grades? - Quora

response.answer_text: They probably don’t think that at all. Instead, they are probably worried that you won’t get into a top college or university. And they may also be worried that the kids of some of their friends are going to get better grades — and better college acceptances — than you; and then they would not have anything to brag about. There is no good answer for this. Almost every kid experiences it, in one form or another, from his parents. Probably the best way to try to de-fuse this is to say something like “Maybe you’re right. I want to get into [chosen university] or somewhere nearly as good, so I am pushing for the best grades I can get. But I know [chosen university] demands well-rounded students, so I’m participating in [list of extra-cirricuars and athletics and non=school activities] so I can show I’m not just an academic nerd.” “What do you think I might need to change or drop, to improve my college application?”. Most likely they won’t have any good answer for that, and they will just tell you to work harder, to which you will agree. However, they might tell you to cut out the TV programs, or your social media postings and reading on the internet, or your use of your smart phone, or hanging out with your buddies. In such a case, they will be right. They have you, and you should cut those back, significantly. Then your grades will go up, and they will nag you less, and everyone will be happier. Except, of course, the moronic kids you were gabbing with on Facebook or Instagram. See how easy it is to make your parents happy, and get them off your back?

A poster I had on the wall read: “If you care about it, you’ll find a way. If you don’t care about it, you’ll find an excuse.” This could be an opportunity for an open discussion. “Good grades” to them might be irrelevant. I’ve had plenty of conferences where a student is getting B, but the parents think A’s are the only acceptable grade… Talk with the parents and explain what actions you ARE doing, and seek reasonable suggestions to improve. I had a conversation with a student (in a parent-teacher conference):Student - “Mr. Hollis, your way just doesn’t work for me... I do it my own way.” Me - “Did you get the correct answers?”Student - “No.”Me - “Then perhaps you should do it my way.”Student - “But I just don’t get you.”Me - “Do you read the text?”Student - “No.”Me - “Do you take notes every class?”Student - “No.”Me - “Do you spend at least 30 minutes on your homework, checking your answers as you go?”Student - “No.”Me - “Do you make a study guide before the test?”Student - “No.”Me - “Do you see me for extra help, before or after school?”Student - “No.”Me - “Well, it’s hard for me to accept your critique that my way doesn’t work for you when you haven’t done it my way. If you have your own way that works for you, that’s fine. But if it doesn’t work for you, you really should try it my way…”
